Nero, when he pro- jected an expedition into iEgypt, ordered them to sail for that country; but, being soon after alarmed by the commotions stirred up by Vindex, he called them back to Italy, where they remained from that time. Their officers, unacquainted with Otho, and closely connected with Vitellius, espoused the interest of the latter. By re- presenting to the men the strength of the legions then on their march to the inva- sion of Italy, and by extolling the valour of the German armies, they drew the whole squadron into their party. As a further proof of their zeal for their new prince, they attracted to his interest the chief municipal towns on the other side of the Po, namely, Mediolanum (c), Novaria, Eporedia, and Vercelles. Of this fact Cae- cina was apprised by dispatches from the officers. But a single squadron, he knew, was not sufficient to defend so large a tract of country.
